Data Explorer truncates links after 380 characters

Ask Question
Asked 12 years, 11 months ago
Modified 12 years, 11 months ago
Viewed 810 times
5

During my experiments with links to the charts I noticed that the resulting links in Data Explorer are truncated after 380 characters.

Try the following query: https://data.stackexchange.com/stackoverflow/query/58883/test-long-url

SELECT 'http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=p&chco=FF0000%2CFFFF00%7CFF8000%2C00FF00%7C00FF00%2C0000FF&chs=450x200&chd=t%3A122%2C42%2C17%2C10%2C8%2C7%2C7%2C7%2C7%2C6%2C6%2C6%2C6%2C5%2C5&chl=122%7C42%7C17%7C10%7C8%7C7%7C7%7C7%7C7%7C6%7C6%7C6%7C6%7C5%7C5&chdl=android%7Cjava%7Cstack-trace%7Cbroadcastreceiver%7Candroid-ndk%7Cuser-agent%7Candroid-webview%7Cwebview%7Cbackground%7Cmultithreading%7Candroid-source%7Csms%7Cadb12345678%7Csollections%7Cactivity|Chart'

The resulting url truncates at %7Cmultithr point, also link name ( Chart) is not applied.

UPDATE

After deploy the truncation is still present. I've checked the query.js source and found the following: 

                                                function encodeColumn(s) {
    if (s != null && s.replace != null) {
        s = s.replace(/[\n\r]/g, " ")
              .replace(/&(?!\w+([;\s]|$))/g, "&")
              .replace(/</g, "<")
              .replace(/>/g, ">")
              .substring(0, 400);
        return s;
    } else {
        return s;
    }
}

I guess that substring(0, 400) should be removed or changed to something more democratic, e.g.: substring(0, 8000).

  • 2
    And you think 380 characters is...not enough?
    –  Josh Darnell
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 21:03
  • @jadarnel27 Well, it may not be enough for the links to Google Charts (check the linked feature-request for details). Of course there could be some behind-the-scenes reasons for the limit Let's wait for devs reply.
    –  Volo
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 21:43
  • 1
    Indeed, my mistake. Good catch!
    –  Josh Darnell
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 21:50
  • fixed and deployed
    –  waffles
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 22:51
  • @waffles The link from my test query is still truncated at multithr part. Check my updated post: there is substring(0, 400) in encodeColumn function.
    –  Volo
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 23:30
  • @Idolon can you try again
    –  waffles
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 23:48
  • @waffles Ok, it's not truncated now, but & in the URL is replaced with &amp (shouldn't there be semicolon at the end?). Check it here: this should create a link to http://google.com/?hl=en&q=Test but creates to http://google.com/?hl=en&ampq=Test instead.
    –  Volo
    Commented Jan 11, 2012 at 0:25
  • @Idolon yeah, Tim is looking into it and possibly posting a related SO question
    –  waffles
    Commented Jan 11, 2012 at 0:28
  • @waffles Thanks. It's almost 3am here so I guess I'll read Tim's question tomorrow morning ;) Just FYI: after last change it's also impossible to add | in the URL as %7C since it is replaced with %257C (vertical line symbol is used in Google Charts URLs). Updated test query accordingly.
    –  Volo
    Commented Jan 11, 2012 at 0:54
Add a comment  | 

1 Answer 1

Reset to default
3

Yeah, the encodeColumn() function was being called a little too early on values that ended up being autolinked. I've patched the relevant code, so hopefully this will be fixed whenever waffles next gets a chance to deploy.

  • did you yank latest from main prior to patching?

    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 21:58

    –  Tim Stone
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 21:59
  • cool, feel free to fix any bugs you see, the data model has changed a bit. it is basically a mirror of gist.
    –  waffles
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 22:00
  • Will do. And yeah, I glanced over the revisions and it's much, much better now.
    –  Tim Stone
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 22:03
  • @TimStone As I understand the issue is substring(0, 400) at line 891
    –  Volo
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 23:22
  • @Idolon Yeah, another deploy is going out that should address this, give it a few minutes.
    –  Tim Stone
    Commented Jan 10, 2012 at 23:47
  • @TimStone Thanks for the fix - works like a charm now.
    –  Volo
    Commented Jan 16, 2012 at 13:10
  • @Idolon Good stuff. Sorry for the delay; your specific problem was easy enough to resolve, but there was a more general issue of whether or not we should try and encode the URL for you (which caused double-encoding in your example).
    –  Tim Stone
    Commented Jan 16, 2012 at 13:17
  • @TimStone NP, I followed your progress in Mercury and was aware that encoding issue wasn't so simple to resolve.
    –  Volo
    Commented Jan 17, 2012 at 11:33
